snippet: The case of Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian politician, has ignited a debate on whether the rules should be changed to rein in high-profile defendants in international tribunals.
abstract: Memo from The Hague; drawn-out war-crimes trial of former Serbian politician Vojislav Seselj has reignited debate over how much bad behavior in the dock should be tolerated before the rules are changed; as international criminal justice expands, courts are likely to face many more military commanders and political leaders who have a flair for the dramatic and are used to getting their way.
lead_paragraph: The case of Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian politician, has ignited a debate on whether the rules should be changed to rein in high-profile defendants in international tribunals.
